newsitem.title: UK: Cr Lyonnais needs even more cash - chairman.
newsitem.headline: Cr Lyonnais needs even more cash - chairman.

text.p: Troubled state-owned French bank Credit Lyonnais will need a bigger than expected injection of government cash, chairman Jean Peyrelevade told Britain's Financial Times.

Peyrelevade told the newspaper in an interview that the bank would need a cash injection of 12 billion francs to strengthen its balance sheet. Last week he said eight to nine billion francs would be needed.
Peyrelevade said the cash injection would help prepare the bank for privatisation or a trade sale to international investors.
But he said this would not occur until mid-1998 at the earliest -- later than expected. He had previously said the sell-off might take place within 18 months.
The newspaper said the bigger cash injection would help the bank cover losses it will have to book on the sale of Credit Lyonnais's European banking network.
Peyrelevade also warned there would be additional provisions for rationalising the domestic retail business.

Provisions of 1.3 billion francs in the first half would cover two-thirds of rationalisation costs, but a further charge would be required in the second half. This would cover cost cutting until 1998, Peyrelevade said in the interview.

About 200 domestic branches -- some 10 percent of the network -- would be closed by the end of 1998 and there would be a further 5,000 job losses. Peyrelevade said he aimed to cut costs by between one percent and two percent a year.

The bigger cash injection would raise the bank's tier-one capital ratio to six percent from 4.5 percent. Last week Peyrelevade said he wanted to raise the ratio to 5.5 percent. --London Newsroom +44 171 542 7717
